assoc_actor_1: CNTE: National Coordination of Education Workers; Teachers (Mexico)
notes: On 4 June 2024, in Oaxaca de Juarez, Oaxaca, teachers from the section 22 of the National Coordinator of Education Workers (CNTE) blocked all accesses, parking lots and places surrounding the International Airport after a meeting with President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador was postponed. Flights were cancelled and a riot was later reported (coded separately).

On 4 June 2024, in Guadalajara, Jalisco, workers from the Welfare Secretariat demonstrated outside the headquarter located in Colonia Arcos Vallarta, demanding improvements in their working conditions. They said that most of them are hired under temporary contracts that have to be renewed every three months, which has caused them to be deprived of benefits such as annual vacations, right of seniority, and payment of bonuses.

On 4 June 2024, in Chetumal, Quintana Roo, around 5000 people including supporters of the Citizens' Movement Party and the candidate for mayor of that party marched through the main avenue denouncing that there was fraud in the elections.

On 4 June 2024, in Morelia, Michoacan de Ocampo, members of three different unions from the Institute of Security and Social Services for State Workers gathered in the facilities of the Institute to demonstrate against the refusal to meet their demands such as the dismissal of several members and authorities, the installation of air conditioning in the work spaces and the application of general working conditions, as well as services such as surveillance, cleaning and fumigation, and the eradication of workplace harassment.

On 4 June 2024, in Merida, Yucatan, hundreds of PAN militants gathered in front of the doors of the National Electoral Institute (INE) to protest and demand a recount of votes. The protesters stated that the state's gubernatorial results are linked to electoral fraud.

assoc_actor_1: MORENA: National Regeneration Movement; PCU: United Chiapas Party; PES: Social Encounter Party; PT: Labor Party; RSP: Social Progressives Networks Party
notes: On 4 June 2024, in San Fernando, Chiapas, around 60 rioters supporters from different parties including Morena, PT, Progressive Social Networks, PES, and the local Chiapas Unidos party demonstrated against the results of the elections and accused that the ballots would be transferred to the Electoral Institute of Citizen Participation headquarters in Tuxtla Gutierrez aboard a non official car. They removed the fence and forcibly entered to the municipal council of the Electoral Institute of Citizen Participation to burn the facilities, vehicles, and electoral documents. A municipal election official jumped from the second floor of the building. An unknown number of people were injured, including members of the Municipal Council who were trying to transfer the electoral documents to Tuxtla Gutierrez.

assoc_actor_1: SNTE: National Union of Education Workers; Teachers (Mexico)
notes: On 4 June 2024, in Tuxtla Gutierrez, Chiapas, teachers from Section 7 of the National Union of Education Workers (SNTE) blocked the west and east entrances of the city while a meeting between the Single National Negotiation Commission of the National Coordinator of Education Workers (CNTE) and President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador was held in Mexico City. The teachers closed the western entrance at La Pochota, and to the east, the entrance leading to the Angel Albino Corzo airport. This section has been on a strike since May 15, demanding the federal and state governments to respond to their demands including the elimination of the educational reform and the Law of the Institute of Security and Social Services of State Workers.

On 4 June 2024, in La Paz, Baja California Sur, a group of teachers members of the Education Workers Movement demonstrated demanding that the government complies with payments they are owed as well as end to repressions of peaceful protests.

On 4 June 2024, in Merida, Yucatan, around a thousand basic education teachers demonstrated at the headquarters of section 33 and 57 of the National Union of Education Workers demanding that their union leaders intervene so that the federal authorities guarantee them a salary increase, the payment of 90 days of bonuses and access to INFONAVIT. They blocked part of Jacinto Caneky Avenue and threatened with an indefinite suspension of work if their demands were not heard. Another source mentioned that there were around 60 demonstrators.
On 4 June 2024, in Jitotol, Chiapas, a group of protesters prevented the counting of votes.

assoc_actor_1: CNTE: National Coordination of Education Workers; Teachers (Mexico)
notes: On 4 June 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, members of the National Coordinator of Education Workers (CNTE) clashed with municipal police officers in front of the National Palace and tore down metal fences on Corregidora Street while a meeting was taking place between CNTE leaders and authorities. Also, they demonstrated against the aggression that teachers in La Raya, Oaxaca faced from the residents who attacked them with sticks, stones and guns, and even retained some of them (coded separately).

assoc_actor_1: CNTE: National Coordination of Education Workers; Teachers (Mexico)

notes: On 4 June 2024, in San Juan Bautista la Raya, Oaxaca, members of the CNTE who blocked the access to the airport to demand wage increases and better labor benefits, were attacked by dozens of residents armed with sticks and machetes who threw rocks and rockets at them. The rioters also fired shots, broke the windows of the protesters' vehicles and burned the pasture where the protesters had parked their vehicles. Seven people were injured, a motorcycle and bicycles were burned and two cars destroyed. The teachers reported that the rioters also retained at least ten teachers. 7 injured.

On 4 June 2024, in Halacho, Yucatan, residents demonstrated against the electoral results and seized electoral material in storage for the counting vote and set it on fire in the streets. Two electoral officials were injured during the altercation. The event was held after the results favored the PAN candidate during the last elections.

On 4 June 2024, in Guadalajara, Jalisco, more than 300 people demonstrated outside the facilities of the Electoral National Institute denouncing that there were irregularities in the vote counting and demanded transparency from the Institute. Amongst the demonstrators, who didn't represent a political party, there were polling station officials who said that at least 111 votes from their stations were not counted.

On 4 June 2024, in San Pedro Garza Garcia, Nuevo Leon, residents of colonia Bosques del Valle to demand a solution to the constant power outages that they have suffered for more than a year. According to protesters, these are caused by a Pemex truck that damages the cables, so they demanded the authorities to place a pole to support the cables or to prohibit the passage of the truck.
On 4 June 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Tlalpan, residents demonstrated demanding access to water. They blocked the Mexico-Cuernavaca highway in both ways.

They marched from the Municipal Committee of the PRI to the local board of the Electoral Institute of the State of Mexico, where they demanded a recount of the votes. More than 200 elements of the Security Secretariat of the State of Mexico were safeguarding the facilities.

They allowed free entry of users to the Metro in stations such as the Hidalgo station, Line 2, and Line 3 at the Indios Verdes, 18 de Marzo, Potrero, Tlatelolco and Universidad stations. They also demonstrated at the Zapata station and in front of the headquarters of the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) located in colonia Buenavista where they burned political propaganda. Their demands include the rejection of the ISSSTE Law of 2007 and the educational reform and a 100% salary increase to the base salary.

On 30 May 2024, in Mexicali, Baja California, health workers demonstrated to demand a relocation as they consider that the current center in Lazaro Cardenas boulevard is not adequate to carry out their job.

The municipal official mentioned that there are only two sexes and that a third is considered a pathology.

On 30 May 2024, in Chilpancingo de los Bravo, Guerrero, a group of around 80 teachers, students and parents Popular High Schools closed the Autopista del Sol to demand the payment of owed amounts for the month of May, as well as official recognition by the Legislative Branch.

They said that if their situation is not solved, they wont vote in the upcoming elections.

notes: On 20 May 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, workers from different areas of the Ministry of Culture, among them members of the National Institute of Anthropology (INAH) and members of the National Democratic Union of Workers of the Ministry of Culture (SNDTSC) protested and blocked Paseo de la Reforma to demand compliance with their labor rights (such as the regularization of personnel), a salary increases and a response from authorities from government agencies to resolve their demands.

On 20 May 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, employees of the Institute of Security and Social Services of the State Workers (ISSSTE) of different states protested outside the Government Palace to demand permanent job positions and an end to precarious job conditions.

On 20 May 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Iztapalapa, more than 30 residents protested and blocked a road at the height of the metro Acatitla in Colonia Santha Martha Acatitla to demand the location of a minor since May 16.
On 20 May 2024, in Monclova, Coahuila de Zaragoza, parents of a primary school staged a sit-in outside the school to denounce the director accused of irregularities and mismanagement of money.

On 20 May 2024, in Chilpancingo de los Bravo, Guerrero, residents protested and set up blockades in Colonia Cuernavaca, in Colonia Lopez Portilo and in Colonia 21 de Septiembre to demand solutions to the lack of water in their neighborhoods.

On 20 May 2024, in Oaxaca de Juarez, Oaxaca, health workers, including nurses and doctors, protested and marched to the central health offices to denounce deficiencies of the civil hospital Dr. Aurelio Valdivieso.

assoc_actor_1: CNTE: National Coordination of Education Workers; Teachers (Mexico)
notes: On 20 May 2024, in Santa Maria del Tule, Oaxaca, members of the CNTE protested and took over the Storage and Dispatch terminal of Pemex and prevented the delivery and distribution of gasoline to demand solutions to their demands, such as lack of administrative personnel.

On 20 May 2024, in Cuacnopalan, Puebla, residents protested and blocked the Cuacnopalan-Oaxaca highway with tires and other objects to demand support from authorities to attend to the spreading forest fires.

On 20 May 2024, in Tlacotepec de Benito Juarez, Puebla, residents protested outside the municipal presidency to demand dialogue about unfinished works, transparency and solutions to the lack of water in the municipalities. After they did not receive solutions, they staged a road block on the 150 Mexico-Veracruz highway near San Jose Tlacuitlapan to demand dialogue about unfinished works, transparency and solutions to the lack of water in the municipalities access to water at the height of San Jose Tlacuitlapan.

On 20 May 2024, in Culiacan Rosales, Sinaloa, a group of people and members of the National Torch movement protested to demand housing and social work for displaced families. Protesters demanded the intervention of the governor and marched to the government palace.

On 20 May 2024, in Heroica Puebla de Zaragoza, Puebla, 15 temporary workers from the Regional Hospital of the Institute of Security and Social Services of State Workers (ISSSTE) protested to demand the delivery of permanent positions and better working conditions.

On 20 May 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Alvaro Obregon, about 60 residents of Colonia El Capulin protested and blocked an intersection to denounce the damages of their homes caused by the intercity train and to demand solutions from the government.

On 20 May 2024, in Naucalpan de Juarez, Mexico, nearly 300 parents of students of the School for Science and Humanities (CCH) protested to demand better security plans and protection for their children before the schoolyear begins. On 20 May 2024, in San Luis Potosi, San Luis Potosi, one dozen representatives of the Teenek indigenous community (coded to Maya Indigenous Group) protested outside the seventh district Court to denounce the imposition of national councilors in an assembly and to demand respect for the autonomy and self-determination of indigenous people and communities.

assoc_actor_1: PAN: National Action Party; PRD: Party of the Democratic Revolution; PRI: Institutional Revolutionary Party; Strength and Heart for Mexico
notes: On 19 May 2024, in Tijuana, Baja California, hundreds of members of the Marea Rosa movement demonstrated to demand respect for their votes and in defense of democracy. The demonstrators denounce the dangers that, according to them, the victory of the Morena party in the next elections would bring. The Marea Rosa, born as a protest against the electoral reforms proposed by President Manuel Lopez Obrador, is integrated by more than 200 non-governmental organizations and is linked to the opposition parties (PRD, PRI, and PAN). The demonstration was part of a nationwide protest where participants expressed their support for the candidate's candidacy for the Strength and Heart for Mexico coalition (coded separately).

source: 24 Horas (Mexico); AP; El Norte; Imagen del Golfo; La Jornada; La Prensa de Monclova; Sintesis; Tiempo; Zeta Tijuana
notes: On 19 May 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, near 95,000 members of the so-called ' Marea Rosa' (Pink Tide) marched to the Zocalo under the slogan 'Save Democracy' demanding the protection of democracy on the upcoming elections. The Marea Rosa, born as a protest against the electoral reforms proposed by President Manuel Lopez Obrador, is integrated by more than 200 non-governmental organizations and is linked to the opposition parties (PRD, PRI, and PAN). Among the demonstrators, there were the candidate for the presidency of Mexico for the Strength and Heart for Mexico coalition and the candidate for governor of Mexico City for the same party. Upon arriving at the Zocalo, they encountered members of the CNTE holding a sit-in. The authorities partitioned the Zocalo to separate the two groups of demonstrators, but there were beatings and insults between some of the demonstrators. The demonstrators themselves separated the group of people who were fighting each other. The demonstration was part of a nationwide protest where participants expressed their support for the candidacy of the candidate of the Strength and Heart for Mexico coalition (coded separately).

On 18 May 2024, near Jofrito, Queretaro, around 200 residents of La Gotera, La Versolilla, Palo Alto, Jofre, Jofrito and La Luz communities blocked the Queretaro-San Luis Potosi highway demanding access to clean water.

On 18 May 2024, in Nuevo Laredo, Tamaulipas, relatives of five civilians killed by military officers one year before and members of Human Rights collectives protested demanding justice for this case, which according to them is an extrajudicial execution.

On 18 May 2024, in La Reforma, Oaxaca, residents set a blockade at the entrance to the municipality and detained the municipal president demanding more resources. The residents threatened to detain officers of the National Electoral Institute if they tried to install the polling station. On 1 June, the elections were suspended in the municipality due to the lack of security conditions. After 47 days, the municipal president and a municipal police officer were released.
On 18 May 2024, in Ocuiltzapotlan, Tabasco, residents blocked the Villahermosa-Frontera highway demanding access to clean water.

notes: On 11 April 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Benito Juarez, for the third consecutive day, residents of the community demonstrated on Insurgentes sur Avenue and Xola against the contamination of the water they are receiving in their houses. On 1 April 2024, in Lagos de Moreno, Jalisco, members of the organization Hasta Encontrarles Lagos de Moreno demonstrated in the main square demanding candidates not to use the topic of missing people and the pain of their relatives as a political instrument. The demonstrators burned tires and cartons at the entrance of the city hall.

On 23 February 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Tlalpan, students from the National School of Anthropology and History (ENAH) blocked central and lateral lanes of Periferico Sur to protest against the lack of payment to cleaning workers, as well as disagreement with the hiring of workers in the area.

On 23 February 2024, in San Cristobal de las Casas, Chiapas, residents of Colonia Guadalupe protested outside the Palace of Justice against the expansion of the walkway that goes from Diego Dugelay Avenue to Guadalupe Square. Madero refinery to demand to the Pemex company to give fix job allocations to thousands of workers who are waiting and that those who have been dismiss be paid in accordance with the law.

notes: On 22 February 2024, in Pachuca de Soto, Hidalgo, unionized workers from the Health Secretariat held a protest at the state Attorney General's Office to demand that the head of the office respond and follow up on the investigation file against their union leader.

assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (Mexico); SNTE: National Union of Education Workers; Teachers (Mexico)

On 22 February 2024, in Tuxtla Gutierrez, Chiapas, dozens of normal students from the Mactumatza Rural Normal School held a protest and blocked the roads to demand the definitive cancellation of the 95 arrest warrants against their classmates. The students blocked the roads with four trucks from different transport lines.

On 22 February 2024, in Guadalajara, Jalisco, a group of retired teachers and professors from the University of Guadalajara held a protest against the new reform. The protest was held after the general rector of the University arrived to the Auditorium to discuss the approval of the modification to the Pension, Retirement and Social Security Benefits Regime.

On 22 February 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Coyoacan, a group of teachers and students from the National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM) held a protest in solidarity with Palestine in front of the Rectorate to request to the authorities to break any academic ties with the State of Israel.

actor2: Police Forces of Mexico (2018-) National Guard

source: El Sol de Acapulco; La Jornada
notes: On 22 February 2024, in Chilpancingo de los Bravo, Guerrero, dozens of families of missing persons protested outside the facilities of the State Executive Commission for Attention to Victims (CEAV) demanding the delivery of the food support that they have been owed for four months, and that has not been fulfilled.

On 22 February 2024, in Chilpancingo de los Bravo, Guerrero, more than 500 students members of the United Front of Public Normals of the State of Guerrero (FUNPEG) held a demonstration to demand the release of 37 of their classmates who were arrested when they tried to take over a bus. The students took over the offices of the General Directorate of the Secretary of Education and destroyed computer equipment and set fire to documentation in the property's explanation. The demonstrators had also previously blocked Parador del Marques road.

On 22 February 2024, in Zacatecas, Zacatecas, a group of former workers from Valparaiso took over the facilities of the Ministry of Finance to protest against the failure of the government to comply with commitments established since 2022 to provide social support.

On 22 February 2024, in Zacatecas, Zacatecas, members of the National Torch Movement marched through the main streets of the Historic Center to demand to the Governor attention and compliance to their request for food support, support for the countryside, among others.

assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (Mexico); SITUAM: National University's Workers Independent Union
notes: On 10 February 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, members of the 'Yo por las 40 horas' organization gathered at the Angel of Independence and marched to the National Palace. The demonstrators demanded that the reform of the working day be discussed in the plenary session of the Chamber of Deputies, to reduce the hours worked per week from 48 to 40. Organizations such as the General Union of Workers of Mexico (UGTM), the Student Union, the Revolutionary Left, Free and Combatives, and the Independent Union of Workers of the Metropolitan Autonomous University (SITUAM) join this protest.

Around 10 February 2024 (as reported), in Acapulco de Juarez, Guerrero, people affected by Hurricane Otis blocked traffic on Avenida Costera Miguel Aleman and Cuauhtemoc to demand the delivery of federal aid. The blockade caused a verbal confrontation between drivers and protesters was reported. Some drivers who got out of their units to forcibly remove the pieces of concrete and other objects that the protesters used to prevent the cars from passing.

On 10 February 2024, in Tixtla de Guerrero, Guerrero, students and parents of the missing students from the Ayotzinapa rural normal school demonstrated in the Ayotzinapa Normal School and declared they continue united in the fight to find the disappeared students.
On 10 February 2024, in Morelia, Michoacan, protesters marched demanding that the bill to reduce the legal working hours be approved in the Congress of the Union (federal congress).

On 3 December 2024, in Ciudad General Escobedo, Nuevo Leon, residents protested against the delay of works to repair a vehicular bridge and to demand solutions from authorities.
On 3 December 2024, in Coxcatlan, Puebla, at least 80 workers from the Calipam Sugar Mill held a protest to demand the payment of their salaries and clarification for their pension.

On 3 December 2024, in Heroica Puebla de Zaragoza, Puebla, residents of Colonia Seda Monsato blocked the Via Corta at the entrance to the Central de Abasto to demand the construction of a pedestrian bridge to cross the highway.
On 3 December 2024, in Escuinapa de Hidalgo, Sinaloa, workers who were fired from the City Council held a protest to demand their owed payment.
On 3 December 2024, in Ciudad Victoria, Tamaulipas, relatives of missing persons protested for a second consecutive day to demand results from authorities in the search of their missing relatives.

admin1: Veracruz de Ignacio de la Llave
notes: On 3 December 2024, in Xalapa-Enriquez, Veracruz, people marched as part of the International Day of Persons with Disabilities. Participants demanded non-discrimination, respect for their human rights, and social inclusion.

On 2 December 2024, in San Francisco de Campeche, Campeche, workers from the Union of Workers of the College of Scientific and Technological Studies of the State of Campeche (Sutcecytecam) held a protest and started a strike demanding immediate payment of their full salary. This event was replicated in another location (coded separately).

On 2 December 2024, in Pomuch, Campeche, workers from the Union of Workers of the College of Scientific and Technological Studies of the State of Campeche (Sutcecytecam) held a protest and started a strike demanding immediate payment of their full salary. This event was replicated in another location (coded separately).

On 2 December 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, a group of residents of the Maclovio Rojas in Tijuana, demonstrated at the Zocalo of Mexico City to demand a meeting with President Claudia Sheinbaum Pardo to inform her of the problems facing their community.

On 2 December 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, tens of merchants blocked Pino Suarez and Eje Central to demand that the authorities to be able to return to their work spaces or be relocated after elements of the state police carried out an operation inside the Izazaga 89 shopping mall and placed suspension seals.

On 2 December 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Iztapalapa, sports promoters blocked the intersection with Eje 6 to demand the payment of their late salaries. The protesters also asked for their contract to be respected.

On 2 December 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Tlalpan, a group of merchants and workers from Plaza Izazaga 89 blocked the area surrounding the shopping center to demand its reopening after its closure last weekend by the Ministry of Economy.

On 2 December 2024, in Colima, Colima, taxi drivers from Tecoman, Armeria and Manzanillo blocked the accesses to the State Government House to protest against the intention of the State Government's Undersecretary of Mobility to remove Tsuru vehicles from circulation as taxis. The protesters stated that this action would affect some of them.

assoc_actor_1: SNTE: National Union of Education Workers; Teachers (Mexico)
notes: On 2 December 2024, in Victoria de Durango, Durango, retired teachers from the SNTE demonstrated and blocked Avenida Cuauhtemoc to demand the payment of their retirement severance insurance.

On 2 December 2024, in Acapulco de Juarez, Guerrero, special education teachers demonstrated at the vicinity of the offices of education in the Acapulco - Coyuca region and took over their facilities to demand that the government comply with their labor demands, including the payment of bonuses, among others.

source: El Sol de Acapulco; La Jornada
notes: On 2 December 2024, in Acapulco de Juarez, Guerrero, retired workers from to the Social Security Institute for Public Servants of the State of Guerrero (ISSSPEG), took over the offices of the State Government's Finance and Administration Secretariat to protest against the lack of payment of their pension for November.

On 2 December 2024, in Atoyac de Alvarez, Guerrero, students from the Ayotzinapa Normal School, groups of relatives of the disappeared, and students from the Autonomous University of Guerrero (UAG) marched as part of the 50th anniversary of the death in combat of Commander Lucio Cabanas Barrientos, a leader of the guerrilla group of the Partido de los Pobres (PDLP). The event was held in a call for unity of all legitimate struggles of the social movement in Mexico.

On 2 December 2024, in Chilpancingo de los Bravo, Guerrero, retirees held a protest against the lack of payment of ISSSPEG. The protesters took over the Alvarez building to demand payment of their pensions corresponding to the months of November and December.
On 2 December 2024, in Chilpancingo de los Bravo, Guerrero, people blocked the city center to demand support after hurricane Otis and John.

On 2 December 2024, in Pachuca de Soto, Hidalgo, hundreds of workers from the Colegio de Bachilleres, affiliated with the Sole Union of Academic Workers of the Colegio de Bachilleres of the State of Hidalgo, protested at the facilities to demand the resignation of the director of the institution.
On 2 December 2024, in Tula de Allende, Hidalgo, motorcyclists protested against high costs. The protesters blocked the Tula-Iturbe boulevard.
On 2 December 2024, in Ecatepec de Morelos, Mexico, residents blocked Via Morelos to demand water drinking supply.
On 2 December 2024, in Toluca de Lerdo, Mexico, firefighters demonstrated outside the City Hall to demand full payment of their Christmas bonus, benefits and pending work days.

On 2 December 2024, in Heroica Puebla de Zaragoza, Puebla, public transport concessionaires protested at the city center to demand an increase in fares. The protesters claimed that there is an unfair competition with the RUTA system and illegal transport in the area.
On 2 December 2024, in Mazatlan, Sinaloa, oncology patients and family members from the oncology area held a protest at the General Hospital over medicines shortage.

On 2 December 2024, in Villahermosa, Tabasco, dozens of workers from Pemex subcontracting companies held a demonstration to demand payment of debts owed by the company for more than a year. The protesters were members of the Frente Amplio de Subcontratistas al Servicio de Pemex (FASP) who gathered outside the Pemex offices, known as 'La Piramide'.

On 2 December 2024, in Ciudad Victoria, Tamaulipas, relatives of missing people, members of the Collective 'For the love of our children and relatives despised and absent from Tamaulipas', blocked the Fidel Velazquez Boulevard to demand justice and greater results in the Investigation of Crimes of Forced Disappearance of Persons.

On 1 December 2024, in Tijuana, Baja California, hundreds of active and retired teachers and members of the Union of Bureaucrats marched from Del Maestro square to Cuauhtemoc boulevard to protest against the law that will reform the ISSSTECALI.

Around 1 December 2024 (as reported), in Isla Aguada, Campeche, people occupied a toll and blocked traffic on Unity bridge to protest against the recently elected municipal commissioner. Following the protest, the Federal Commission of Electricity (CFE) cut the electricity supply in the whole town, although it has not been confirmed whether this was an act of retaliation.

On 1 December 2024, in Heroica Puebla de Zaragoza, Puebla, relatives, friends, and coworkers of a taxi driver who died in a car accident with a municipal police car on 25 November 2024 marched from 25 Oriente and 16 de Septiembre streets to the offices of the State General Judiciary (FGE) to demand justice.

On 30 November 2024, in Saucillo, Chihuahua, around 200 women who are normalista students of Ricardo Flores Magon school marched from the intersection of Universidad and Riva Palacio avenues towards the downtown to demand the dismissal of their school's management.

Around 30 November 2024 (as reported), in Guadalajara, Jalisco, members of the Committee of Solidarity with Palestine marched from Andador Escorza (now known as Andador Palestina Libre) to Plaza de Armas (known as Plaza Imelda Virgen) to denounce 'the Israeli genocide' and demand to break diplomatic relations with Israel.

Around 30 November 2024 (as reported), in Cuernavaca, Morelos, parents of students of Ing. Aquiles Cordova Moral school, in Emiliano Zapata, protested in front of the offices of the federal Secretariat of Wellbeing to demand a correct use of public funds.

On 30 November 2024, in Jiutepec, Morelos, parents of students of Benito Juarez primary school blocked Cuauhnahuac boulevard to demand justice for a female student who was victim of sexual abuse in the school's premises on 26 November 2024.

Around 30 November 2024 (as reported), in the municipality of San Nicolas de los Garza, Nuevo Leon, members of The Alliance of Transport Users protested against the price increase of the tariffs during an inauguration of medical facilities attended by President Sheinbaum and Governor Garcia.

On 29 November 2024, in San Francisco de Campeche, Campeche, INAH employees and members of the National Democratic Union of Workers of the Ministry of Culture held a protest against the budget cuts planned for 2025 in key sectors such as health, education, public security and culture. The protest was held in front of the Casa Teniente del Rey Museum.

On 29 November 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, people marched demanding that the Mexican government break relations with Israel. The march was from the US embassy to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (SRE). The event was made in the context of the International Day of Solidarity with the Palestinian People. The protesters also demanded that the United States stop providing further funding to the Israeli army and lift the veto it has imposed against the resolutions of the United Nations Organization that call for an unconditional ceasefire.

On 29 November 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Tlalpan, construction workers blocked the entrance of Vasco de Quiroga Street to Periferico around Cardiology Hospital demanding payment of their salaries from the hospital director. The protesters were involved in the construction of the hospital.

On 29 November 2024, in Victoria de Durango, Durango, members of the Union of Independent Bricklayers demonstrated at the Municipal Government offices in the Administrative Unit to demand a dialogue with the Mayor. The protesters accused the Municipal Environmental personnel of arbitrarily arriving at the brickyards and closing them without prior notice.

On 29 November 2024, in Buenavista, Mexico, residents of Colonia El Paraje Fimesa III burned tires and blocked Jose Lopez Portillo road to demand the release of two residents detained by municipal police who entered their community during an operation.

On 29 November 2024, in Culiacan Rosales, Sinaloa, residents demonstrated outside the State Congress to demand to the Governor to provide security conditions for the population. The event was held prior to the Governor's third government report.

assoc_actor_1: Teachers (Mexico); SNTE: National Union of Education Workers
notes: On 29 November 2024, in Chilpancingo de los Bravo, Guerrero, about 150 teachers and members of the National Union of Education Workers (SNTE) blocked both directions of Vicente Guerrero Boulevard demanding that the Guerrero Education Secretariat (SEG) comply with the petition requested in writing months ago. Among the demands, the teachers asked for schools to be rebuilt since they were affected by hurricanes Otis and John, and the payment of insurances.
On 29 November 2024, in Chilpancingo de los Bravo, Guerrero, teachers members of Guerrero State High School Workers' Union marched to demand a salary increase.

On 29 November 2024, in San Luis Potosi, San Luis Potosi, residents of Colonia El Terremoto blocked the boulevard next to Juarez's water distribution facilities to demand the restoration of the water supply in the area.

On 28 November 2024, in Ensenada, Baja California, thousands of workers held a protest against the reform to their sector and the lack of delayed payments. The protesters sought to sign agreements that would guarantee their participation in the reform of ISSSTECALI. This event was replicated in other locations in the state (coded separately).

On 28 November 2024, in Tecate, Baja California, city workers took over the offices of the State Revenue Collection Office to protest against the reform to their sector and the lack of delayed payments. The protesters started a strike. This event was replicated in other locations in the state (coded separately).
On 28 November 2024, in La Paz, Baja California Sur, pensioners and retirees held a protest against the lack of payment of bonuses. The protest was held before the deputy and former union leader.

On 28 November 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, 1500 merchants held a protest and demanded that the head of the Government of Mexico City resolve unfulfilled commitments since the coronavirus pandemic led by the current general director of the Metro. The protesters demanded to be discharged of fines during that time, where they also experienced economy lost due to the pandemic.

On 28 November 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Xochimilco, former workers of the mayor's office blocked the intersections of Muyuguarda and Division del Norte extension to demand a working table with the heads of Administration, Finance and Human and Labor Resources of the mayor's office. The protesters demanded Labor Justice and compliance with their petitions.

On 28 November 2024, in Victoria de Durango, Durrango, merchants held a protest outside the City Council session to express their dissatisfaction with the removal of the traditional nativity scene that was placed next to the Duck Lake. The protesters stated that they were not offered any alternative for their sales.

On 28 November 2024, in Acapulco de Juarez, Guerrero, residents of Colonia Villa Hermosa de las Flores took over the El Cayaco water treatment plant to demand the dredging of a drain located on Salinas Sotelo Street. The protesters demanded that the Commission for Potable Water and Sewerage of the Municipality of Acapulco (CAPAMA) be responsible as this has led to accidents and respiratory illnesses.

On 28 November 2024, in Chilpancingo de los Bravo, Guerrero, members of the Association of Retirees and Pensioners of the State of Guerrero protested to demand from the Social Security Institute for Public Servants of the State of Guerrero (ISSSPEG) the payment of the monthly payment for the month of November 2024.

On 28 November 2024, in Atotonilco de Tula, Hidalgo, residents of 16 de enero street protested to demand that the municipal government clean the sewer system on Artesanos street. The protesters stated that this could cause health problems.

actor2: Police Forces of Mexico (2018-) State Police
notes: On 28 November 2024, in Tizayuca, Hidalgo, residents held a demonstration against a construction of a new adjacent houses and what they called an arbitrary decision to tear down a perimeter wall. The demonstration turned violent when residents and state and municipal police officers who were in charge of guarding the works clashed in a verbal and physical confrontation. Five people were arrested. Eight people were injured.

On 28 November 2024, in Tlalnepantla, Mexico, parents blocked the side lane of the Periferico Norte near Valle Dorado, to denounce the lack of teachers at Public Secondary School 264 'Moises Sainz'. The protesters asked for the intervention of state authorities, in addition to requesting the reinstatement of a teacher as director of the school.

On 28 November 2024, in Santa Maria de Ostula, Michoacan, at least 3000 residents marched from the community of Xakalan to La Placita on the Lazaro Cardenas-Colima coastal highway to ask the Collegiate Court on Administrative and Labor Matters to resolve in their favor in the session scheduled next week related to a land conflict. The residents held a land conflict for thousand hectares that were invaded by small landowners from La Placita. The conflict escalated after a fight in which there were outbreaks of violence in 2009. The residents managed to recover part of the Xacalan property.

On 28 November 2024, in Jiutepec, Morelos, parents of the Benito Juarez elementary school in Colonia Tlahuapan blocked the Cuauhnahuac Boulevard to demand increased security both inside and outside the school. The protest occurred after a man entered the school on the afternoon of November 26 and abused a student.

On 28 November 2024, in Pishishi, Oaxaca, parents of the Macedonio Alcala school blocked the Transstmica highway on the Tehuantepec-Salina Cruz to demand the solution of an internal conflict that affects their children's classes. The protest arose due to clashes between teachers and the school management.

On 28 November 2024, in Heroica Puebla de Zaragoza, Puebla, a dozen parents of the 6 de enero de 1915 elementary school protested at the facilities to ask for greater surveillance and security, after a student carried a knife and threatened to hurt his classmates.

On 28 November 2024, in Santiago de Queretaro, Queretaro, residents of fraccionamiento Santiago marched and blocked Paseo Cinco de Febrero to protest against the construction of a plant of the company Gas Rosa near their homes.

admin1: Veracruz de Ignacio de la Llave
notes: On 28 November 2024, in Rio Blanco, Veracruz, residents of various neighborhoods held a protest against the CAEV water manager and the lack of water. The protesters asked to be attended by the municipal president.

On 28 November 2024, in San Cristobal de las Casas, Chiapas, around 200 people gathered at Guadalupe's church square and marched across the city to demand peace and security in Chiapas and justice for the murder of a Catholic priest on 20 October 2024 (coded separately). Among the demonstrators, it is likely that there were members of the Catholic church since there was at least one flag with the Virgin Mary, and the church of Guadalupe, where the parish priest officiated, is Catholic.

assoc_actor_1: Former Government of Mexico (2018-); Labor Group (Mexico)
notes: On 27 November 2024, in Mexicali, Baja California, former members of the Bureaucrats Union in Mexicali and retired teachers along with a former local deputy protested at the State Congress against the reform of the ISSSTECALI law and to demand the sanitation of the ISSSTECALI's accounts.

source: AFN - Tijuana; La Jornada; La Silla Rota; Zeta Tijuana
notes: On 27 November 2024, in Playas de Rosarito, Baja California, over 200 members of the Bureaucrats Union interrupted the weekly conference of the state governor at the Metropolitan Convention Center to protest against the reform of the ISSSTECALI law that would extend their retirement age.

On 27 November 2024, in Tijuana, Baja California, city workers held a protest against the reform to their sector and the lack of delayed payments. The protesters sought to sign agreements that would guarantee their participation in the reform of ISSSTECALI. This event was replicated in other locations in the state (coded separately).

On 27 November 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Benito Juarez, for the second consecutive day, residents of Colonia Narvarte protested to demand the return of dogs that the authorities seized from an animal shelter located in the intersection of Xochicalco and La Morena due to their poor health condition. The protesters blocked Eje 1 Poniente Cuauhtemoc.

Around 27 November 2024 (as reported), in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, people protested in front of the Senate against the reform that will eliminate seven public agencies, including the National Institute of Transparency, Access to Information and Protection of Personal Data (Inai).
On 27 November 2024, in Victoria de Durango, Durango, farmers held a protest to denounce the lack of payment from the government programs 'Sembrando Vida'.

On 27 November 2024, in Acapulco de Juarez, Guerrero, around 200 farmers affected by hurricane Otis used trunks, stones, and vehicles to block Diamante viaduct and Acapulco-Pinotepa Nacional federal road to demand financial assistance.

On 27 November 2024, in Acapulco de Juarez, Guerrero, people affected by hurricane John blocked Costera Miguel Aleman avenue to demand financial assistance. Some pedestrians and drivers affected by the block verbally confronted the protesters.

Around 27 November 2024 (as reported), in Acapulco de Juarez, Guerrero, parents of students of the morning shift at Francisco Perez Rios primary school blocked the accesses to the school to demand an audit of the financial assistance granted by the federal government to fix the damages caused by hurricane Otis.

On 27 November 2024, in Chilpancingo de los Bravo, Guerrero, around 20 normalista students protested in unspecified locations where several men were killed to demand justice for them and for the 43 normalista students from Ayotzinapa who disappeared in 2014.

On 27 November 2024, in Pachuca de Soto, Hidalgo, around 50 normalista students of Normal Luis Villarreal de El Mexe school blocked the accesses to the central bus station and Javier Rojo Gomez and Nuevo Hidalgo boulevards, and retained three buses belonging to ADO and ODT businesses. The students demand that both companies comply with an agreement that they suspectedly had with the students and borrow them transport vehicles. The students intend to use the vehicles to transport people to events that will commemorate the anniversary of their school.

On 27 November 2024, in Pachuca de Soto, Hidalgo, members of Rafael Ramirez National Federation of Revolutionary Students (FENERRR), linked to the National Torch Movement, protested in front of the Government Palace and blocked Madero avenue to demand housing assistance for young people and outstanding payments for teachers.

On 27 November 2024, in the municipality of Texcoco (coded to Texcoco de Mora), Mexico, unionized teachers of the Autonomous University of Chapingo (STAUACh) blocked the accesses to the university to demand the reinstatement of dismissed teachers and to protest against abuses of authority.

Around 27 November 2024 (as reported), in Cuernavaca, Morelos, teachers and members of the Education Movement of Bases (MMB) protested in front of the State Palace to demand an audit of new teaching positions to avoid favoritism in its allocations.

On 27 November 2024, in Jiutepec, Morelos, parents of students of Benito Juarez primary school blocked the accesses to the school and Cuauhnahuac boulevard by Colonia Tlahuapan to demand justice and security, following the attempted sexual abuse committed by a man against a female student the previous day.

On 27 November 2024, in Villahermosa, Tabasco, around 300 business owners and employees of PEMEX's subcontractors protested in a commercial plaza in the intersection of Ruiz Cortines and Periferico roads to demand outstanding payments.

source: 24 Horas (Mexico); E-Consulta; GardaWorld; La Jornada; La Verdad
notes: On 27 November 2024, in Calpulalpan, Tlaxcala, farmers from Mexico, Hidalgo, and Tlaxcala states set barricades with trunks and tires to block traffic on km. 182+400 of Arco Norte highway, by the municipality of Calpulalpan, to demand compensations for the lands that were expropriated for the construction of the road.

admin1: Veracruz de Ignacio de la Llave
notes: Around 27 November 2024 (as reported), in Tihuatlan, Veracruz de Ignacio de la Llave, residents of the community of Lazaro Cardenas blocked the road to Costa Rica to demand that the owners of a dog that has attacked eight people assume the health care costs of the victims.

On 26 November 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Benito Juarez, residents of Colonia Narvarte protested to demand the return of dogs that the authorities seized from an animal shelter located in the intersection of Xochicalco and La Morena due to their poor health condition.

On 26 November 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Iztapalapa, feminist activists of the National Front of Sorority protested in front of the Eastern Penitentiary to demand the conviction of a man who is a prisoner of the center. The man suspectedly used AI to create and sell nude pictures of eight female students of the National Polytechnic Institute (IPN) in October 2023. Members of 'No More Innocent Prisoners' national collective also protested to demand the release of the man and denounce 'radical feminism'.

Around 26 November 2024 (as reported), in Ciudad de Mexico - Milpa Alta, residents of San Pedro Atocpan blocked km. 17,5 of Mexico-Oaxtepec federal road to demand justice for the murder of a woman in Milpa Alta on 23 November 2024 (coded separately).

Around 26 November 2024 (as reported), in Monclova, Coahuila de Zaragoza, vendors protested in front of the municipal presidency offices to demand the prohibition of an itinerant commercial caravan known as Moroleon for suspected unfair competition.

On 26 November 2024, in Sabinas, Coahuila de Zaragoza, parents of students of Miguel Hidalgo primary school blocked the accesses to the school to demand the dismissal of a janitor due to his history of addictions.

On 26 November 2024, in Acapulco de Juarez, Guerrero, retired people linked to the Social Security Institute for Public Servants of the State of Guerrero (ISSSPEG) blocked Costera Miguel Aleman avenue to demand outstanding payments.
Around 26 November 2024 (as reported), in Acapulco de Juarez, Guerrero, teachers of special education protested in Juan N. Alvarez square to demand better labor conditions.

assoc_actor_1: SNTE: National Union of Education Workers; Teachers (Mexico)
notes: On 26 November 2024, in Chilpancingo de los Bravo, Guerrero, members of the National Union of Education Workers (SNTE) blocked Vicente Guerrero avenue, in front of the offices of the Directorate General of Education Services to demand better labor and financial conditions.

Around 26 November 2024 (as reported), in Chilpancingo de los Bravo, Guerrero, around 50 members of 'Lupita Rodriguez' collective protested at the Anti-Monument to the 43 to demand justice for the 43 normalista students from Ayotzinapa who disappeared in 2014.

On 26 November 2024, in Pachuca de Soto, Hidalgo, parents of students of Juan C. Doria primary school, in Colonia Juan C. Doria, blocked the accesses to the school to demand the dismissal of its director for suspectedly mistreating students.

On 26 November 2024, on Arco Norte highway (coded to Tula de Allende), Hidalgo, residents of the communities around the Endho dam blocked traffic around Tula II toll to demand measures against the water lily accumulated in the dam, which facilitates the emergence of disease-carrying mosquitoes.

Around 26 November 2024 (as reported), in the municipality of Nezahualcoyotl (coded to Ciudad Nezahualcoyotl), Mexico, transport drivers of 'Rutas Hermanas' association blocked Bordo de Xochiaca avenue and later protested in front of the Control Courts of Nezahualcoyotl's Penitentiary and Social Reinsertion Center to demand that two extortionists who were arrested receive a fair sentence and are not released from prison. The arrestees are suspected members of Los Pelones Cartel who extort transport drivers and vendors in the east of Mexico state.

On 26 November 2024, on Mexico-Queretaro highway (coded to Tultitlan de Mariano Escobedo), Mexico, residents of the village and the ejido of San Francisco Chilpan and Colonias Ampliacion Sardana, Benito Juarez, and Sierra de Guadalupe used trucks to block traffic to demand the State Judiciary to investigate the dispossession of properties by the mayor's office of Tultitlan.

source: La Jornada; La Voz de Michoacan
notes: On 26 November 2024, in Morelia, Michoacan de Ocampo, around 50 Nahua farmers from Santa Maria de Ostula protested in front of the offices of the Federal Judiciary to demand the restitution of over 1,000 hectares of land in Xayacalan, La Canahuancera, and Las tres Majahuas.

Around 26 November 2024 (as reported), in Cuernavaca, Morelos, parents of students of an unspecified primary school protested to demand better education services to the Institute of Basic Education of the State of Morelos (IEBEM).

Around 26 November 2024 (as reported), in Jiutepec, Morelos, parents of students of an unspecified primary school protested to demand better education services to the Institute of Basic Education of the State of Morelos (IEBEM).

Around 26 November 2024 (as reported), in Zacatepec de Hidalgo, Morelos, parents of students of an unspecified primary school protested to demand better education services to the Institute of Basic Education of the State of Morelos (IEBEM).

Around 26 November 2024 (as reported), in Oaxaca de Juarez, Oaxaca, employees of the Civil Hospital Doctor Aurelio Valdivieso blocked Violetas street to demand outstanding payments to the Secretariat of Health and the Mexican Insitute of Social Security (IMSS).

Around 26 November 2024 (as reported), in Oaxaca de Juarez, Oaxaca, students and parents of students of Center for Technology, Industrial, and Services Studies No. 103 blocked 5 Senores avenue to demand that the school is not closed.

assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (Mexico); SNTE: National Union of Education Workers; Teachers (Mexico)
notes: On 26 November 2024, in Hermosillo, Sonora, retired teachers linked to the National Union of Education Workers (SNTE) and teachers from the municipalities of Etchojoa, Huatabampo, Alamos, Navojoa, Ciudad Obregon, Empalme, Hermosillo, Caborca, and San Luis Rio Colorado protested in front of the Government Palace to demand bonuses for Christmas and the Teacher's Day.

On 26 November 2024, in Santa Ana Ixtlahuatzingo, Tlaxcala, at least 50 residents blocked Tenancingo-Malinalco, Tenancingo-Villa Guerrero, and Tenancingo-Tenango del Valle federal roads and Genaro Diaz Manonstreet to demand the release of five members of Tenancingo's Water Committee that had been previously arrested. notes: Around 26 November 2024 (as reported), in Boca del Rio, Veracruz de Ignacio de la Llave, people protested to demand justice for a woman who was a victim of gender violence. The woman was strangled by her ex partner while she was in a hospital.

admin1: Veracruz de Ignacio de la Llave
notes: On 19 November 2024, in Cordoba, Veracruz de Ignacio de la Llave, parents protested against a teacher accused of discrimination, verbal aggression and bullying.

notes: On 19 November 2024, in Poza Rica de Hidalgo, Veracruz de Ignacio de la Llave, feminist students and activist from the University of Veracruz protested to demand the university to expel a student accused of sexual aggression against other students.

On 19 November 2024, in Tabasco, Zacatecas, police officers protested to demand the governor to open an investigation against members of the members of the Immediate Reaction Forces of Zacatecas (FRIZ) after the arrest of two men on Sunday.

On 19 November 2024, in Petatlan, Guerrero, teachers of the Technology University of Costa Grande linked to the National Union of Higher Education (SNES) occupied the premises of the university to demand the dismissal of the chancellor and the woman academic secretariat due to a suspected misappropriation of funds.

On 18 November 2024, in Ciudad del Carmen, Campeche, residents protested and blocked the Chumpan-Adelaida highway claiming that the mayor imposed the new commissioners. This protest occurred amid the election of the municipal commissioners in Campeche state.

location: Ciudad de Mexico - Cuajimalpa de Morelos
notes: On 18 November 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuajimalpa de Morelos, residents of Colonia Contadero protested and blocked the Mexico-Toluca highway to demand authorities to remove mounds of earth that have been set in the pedestrian crossings.

On 18 November 2024, in Acapulco de Juarez, Guerrero, around 30 people from several neighborhoods protested and blocked the coastline to demand their inclusion into the census and the payment of financial support to those affected by Hurricane John.

On 18 November 2024, in La Y Griega, Guerrero, more than 3000 farmers from 60 municipalities blocked the federal highway Acapulco-Zihuatanejo at the junction of y Griega and Quinto Patio to demand equal treatment and receive support from the government after they were affected by Hurricane John.

On 18 November 2024, in Chilpancingo de los Bravo, Guerrero, residents of Colonia Galeana protested and blocked two roads to demand their inclusion in the census to receive support for victims of Hurricane John.

On 18 November 2024, in Huixquilucan de Degollado, Mexico, residents protested and blocked the Mexico-Toluca highway against a construction site that is considered an invasion of their property. Participants lifted the protest after one hour.

On 18 November 2024, in Uruapan, Michoacan de Ocampo, dozens of people protested outside the Pemex plant and protested simultaneously at the intersection of Zumpimito and the Libramiento Oriente after a patient was denied medical attention because of the lack of doctors. Protesters demanded the provision of doctors and solutions.
On 18 November 2024, in Heroica Puebla de Zaragoza, Puebla, members of the organization 28 de Octubre protested and marched to the Zocalo. Motive for the protest is unknown.

On 17 November 2024, in Centauro del Norte, Campeche, residents protested and blocked the Villahermosa-Escarcega highway against the intervention of the municipal president and to denounce the unfair elections of a commissioner.

On 17 November 2024, in Xkuncheil, Campeche, residents closed access to the town to protest and denounce that the city council did not register all of their candidates in the election process for municipal agents and commissioners.
On 17 November 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, anti-war activists protested in front of the Monument to the Revolution to demand peace in Ukraine.
On 17 November 2024, in Tlajomulco de Zuniga, Jalisco, around 600 people marched to demand to the authorities to punish the perpetrator who killed two people, including a baby.

On 17 November 2024, in Jiutepec, Morelos, former workers and retirees blocked various streets to protest against the lack of response from the interim mayor regarding the debts owed to retirees and pensioners of the City Council.

On 17 November 2024, in Heroica Puebla de Zaragoza, Puebla, relatives of a man who has been missing for 10 months held a demonstration to demand justice after intermediate hearing against the only person arrested will be held on November 22.

notes: On 17 November 2024, in Jaltipan de Morelos, Veracruz de Ignacio de la Llave, residents demonstrated and blocked the Jaltipan-Acayucan highway and burned tires and simultaneously demonstrated outside the municipal palace to demand justice for the death of teenager.

admin1: Veracruz de Ignacio de la Llave
notes: On 17 November 2024, in Xalapa-Enriquez, Veracruz de Ignacio de la Llave, residents of Jaltipan de Morelos protested outside the facilities of the State Attorney General's Office (FGE) to demand justice for the death of teenager.

On 16 November 2024, around Jerusalen, Durango, people blocked the water flow to protest against leaks and the failure of the Federal Government and Conagua to comply with the commitments established with users of Irrigation Module 03. The participants also protested against the poor quality of the infrastructure works that have generated leaks in their lands

On 16 November 2024, in Chimalhuacan, Mexico, residents from Colonia Xochiaca blocked the intersection of Bordo de Xochiaca Avenida to protest against the intention of the local authority to host a fair in the same place and on the same date that had been scheduled for the celebration of the fifteenth edition of the Olive Fair.

On 16 November 2024, in Tlalnepantla, Mexico, residents, social and cultural groups gathered to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the explosions that occurred in facilities in San Juan Ixhuatepec, which left hundreds dead and injured. The participants stated that it is essential to insist on the safety of the population and that civil organizations contribute to raising their voices in the demand for greater safety by the authorities and the prohibition of the operation of chemical industries, including PEMEX.
On 16 November 2024, in Monterrey, Nuevo Leon, relatives of a family that had an accident the day before in Guadalupe municipality held a protest to demand justice against the responsible.
On 16 November 2024, in Monterrey, Nuevo Leon, retirees held a protest to demand a pension increase.

On 16 November 2024, in Monterrey, Nuevo Leon, around 50 members of the Public Transport Users Alliance held a demonstration to reject the increase in public transport fares. The participants gathered outside the Juarez Market and collected signatures to add to a collective appeal.
On 16 November 2024, in Ciudad Sabinas Hidalgo, Coahuila, more than 300 people women marched to demand justice for the feminicide of a young woman who disappeared and was found killed.
On 16 November 2024, in Oaxaca de Juarez, Oaxaca, family and friends protested against the disappearance of human rights defenders during the screening of the second government report.

On 16 November 2024, in Santiago de Queretaro, Queretaro, around 200 people marched to demand justice for those who were killed on November 9 at the Cantaritos bar (coded separately). The people held a silent march demanding peace and justice for the victims. The protest was led by the former rector of the Autonomous University of Queretaro (UAQ), representatives of 27 civil society organizations, including an activist for sexual diversity (LGBTQ+ community) and citizen rights.

On 16 November 2024, in Matehuala, San Luis Potosi, parents of the Margarita Maza Elementary School took over the school facilities to protest against the lack of a teacher for the fifth grade. The parents demanded an immediate intervention from educational authorities to resolve the lack of personnel.

On 15 November 2024, in Guanajuato, Guanajuato, residents from rural communities protested at the municipal presidency against the process of electing rural delegates.

On 15 November 2024, in Chilpancingo de los Bravo, Guerrero, residents protested to demand a proper investigation into the recent killing of the mayor (coded separately) and to denounce the arrest of a man considered a scapegoat and demanded justice and accountability.

On 15 November 2024, in Tepotzotlan, Mexico, residents protested and blocked the toll booth on the Mexico-Queretaro highway to demand the release of a man who was arrested and accused of complicity in a multiple homicide.

On 15 November 2024, in Tlalnepantla, Mexico, 300 people including freight transportation drivers, taxis, and members of the 23 de marzo association demonstrated to demand the release of a cargo truck and denounced abuses by a truck company that charged excessive fees for towing and storage. On 15 November 2024, in Ciudad de Chignahuapan, Puebla, residents protested and blocked key roads and access points and the Chignahuapan-Tlaxco highway to demand the dismissal of the Municipal Council accused of acting in personal interests and failing to represent the local population.

On 15 November 2024, in Zacatecas, Zacatecas, a group of farmers protested at state congress to demand more support from deputies for the adequate allocation of funds to address issues such as outdated irrigation equipment, prolonged drought, recent flooding, and the security challenges facing the region.

On 15 November 2024, in Zimapan, Hidalgo, nearly a thousand miners, together with truck drivers dedicated to transporting the metal extracted from the veins, and public transporters marched towards Pachuca to demand that state authorities intervene to prevent the Cement Union from entering their municipality.
On 15 November 2024, in Oaxaca de Juarez, Oaxaca, a group of workers from the Civil Hospital blocked the Porfirio Diaz road near the fountain of the 8 regions. The motive of the protest is unknown.

notes: On 13 November 2024, in Arriaga, Chiapas, seven migrants from Nicaragua, El Salvador and Peru began a hunger strike after the Attorney General's Office (FGR) refuses to open an investigation case for the kidnapping of which they were victims at the end of August.

On 13 November 2024, in San Javier, Chiapas, residents protested to demand the federal and state governments to address their demands. Participants were members of the Indigenous Xi'nich' organization and demanded justice after the massacre of five people that occurred on November 2006 in the town of Viejo Velasco. The event was held during an assembly.

On 13 November 2024, in Tuxtla Gutierrez, Chiapas, a group of representatives from the municipality of Pantelho held a protest to demand the removal of their municipal council. The protesters argued that they do not know its members and that they have not presented themselves to the community. The participants held the event in front of the facilities of the Congress of Chiapas, stating that more than 60 communities have agreed to demand the removal of the current municipal council.
On 13 November 2024, in Chihuahua, Chihuahua, people held a protest and took over the Tax offices against bullfights.

On 12 November 2024, in Tijuana, Baja California, members of the Independent Health Workers Union (FINTRAS) blocked the 'Mano Amiga' bridge to protest against the lack of progress to solve the demands submitted months ago related to their labor conditions and pending payments.
On 12 November 2024, in Cabo San Lucas, Baja California Sur, around 50 people held a protest against the lack of water supply.

On 12 November 2024, in San Francisco de Campeche, Campeche, former employees of the City Council held a protest and prevented deputies from accessing the Congress. The protesters asked for clarification of the legal situation of a government official.

On 12 November 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, teachers members of the National Front of Upper Secondary Education Unions blocked all access to the Chamber of Deputies to demand compliance to their demands, including the payment of welfare measures and salary policy.

On 12 November 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, dozens of merchants gathered outside the central offices of the STC Metro to request a dialogue with authorities to present their cases against fraud. assoc_actor_1: MST: Social Movement for the Earth; PCM: Mexican Communist Party

On 12 November 2024, in Acapulco de Juarez, Guerrero, for the second day in a row, vendors of craftwork from La Diana, Dalia, and Pueblito markets, and touristic workers from Barra Vieja, San Andres, and Lomas de Chapultepec affected by hurricane John held a press conference at Quebec square and then blocked Costera Miguel Aleman avenue to demand to be registered in a census and granted financial assistance.

On 12 November 2024, in Acapulco de Juarez, Guerrero, workers of several organizations of tourist service providers in the Federal Maritime Land Zone (Zofemat) held a protest to demand financial support to the authorities after being affected by the lack of tourism in Acapulco.

On 12 November 2024, in Acapulco de Juarez, Guerrero, teachers and parents of the 'Miguel Aleman Valdes' Kindergarten blocked Vicente Guerrero Boulevard to denounce that the National Guard intends to take over the street that connects this educational institution with the construction of the barracks in Colonia Postal.

On 12 November 2024, in Chilpancingo de los Bravo, Guerrero, more than 100 workers and journalists from different media outlets stormed the plenary hall of the local Congress to demand respect for their work. The event was held after threats made by a local deputy, who over the weekend threatened to take legal action against reporters and media outlets that reported on the ride she took in a Tesla Cybertruck.

On 12 November 2024, in Mixquiahuala de Juarez, Hidalgo, friends and relatives of the police officers gathered and placed banners to claim justice for the officers accused to free two prisoners from a jail. The relatives claimed that the prisoners pointed a gun at the police officers and threatened them.
On 12 November 2024, in Tlajomulco de Zuniga, Jalisco, relatives and residents gathered to demand justice for a double femicide that occurred in Cuauhtemoc. The event was held during a funeral mass.

On 12 November 2024, in Jiutepec, Morelos, auxiliary authorities from various colonies gathered at the Tejalpa intersection as a protest against the non-payment of their compensations corresponding to the month of October. The city hall workers demanded the payment of their owed debts.

Around 11 November 2024 (as reported), in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, around 30 vendors protested in front of the offices of the Metro Collective Transportation System (STC) to demand more space for their stores.

Around 11 November 2024 (as reported), in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, around 500 members of the National Assembly of Electrical Energy Users (ANUEE) marched from the Red Building of the Federal Commission of Electricity (CFE) on 164 Reforma avenue, in Colonia Juarez, to the Federal Consumer Protection Agency (PROFECO) in Colonia Condesa, to demand lower electricity fares. The protestors blocked the intersection of Reforma and Insurgentes avenue during the march.

notes: On 2 October 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, 8000 people, including university students, Indigenous groups, and civil society organizations, demonstrated to commemorate the 56th anniversary of the student massacre and marched to the Zocalo of the city to demand justice and punishment of those involved in the student massacre in 1968. Demonstrators launched four explosives at police officers as well as at the metro station Tlatelolco and vandalized bus stops, government buildings, and bank windows. A group of around 150 masked people and members of the Black Block organization pulled the camera of a reporter to prevent him from filming and threw water in his face. Demonstrators set fire to the doors of City Hall and threw stones, rockets and explosive devices at the building. Police officers repelled the aggression and threw stones and activated fire extinguishers. Two members of the Black Bloc were injured as a result.

On 26 September 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, members of the Popular Union of Street Vendors (UPVA) 28 October and the National Torcho Movement marched from Juarez avenue and on Reforma avenue towards the municipal palace, where they gathered and blocked the way to demand justice for the 43 normalista students from Ayotzinapa that disappeared in 2014 and the killing of a woman colleague. This event is part of a nationwide protest call in commemoration of the tenth anniversary of the disappearance of the students, which includes demonstrations in other cities (coded separately).

Around 26 September 2024 (as reported), in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, around 25 members of the trans community used a rope and motorbikes to block Eje Central and Juarez in Colonia Centro, to protest against the suspected discrimination of a trans woman. According to the demonstrators, the Secreatariat of Foreign Affairs (SRE) denied her a passport for being trans.

source: 24 Horas (Mexico); El Sol de Acapulco; Milenio; Tabasco Hoy
notes: On 26 September 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, over 10.000 citizens, students and members of unions and organizations of teachers and farmers marched from Angel de la Independencia and on Reforma avenue towards the Constitution Square, to demand justice for the 43 normalista students from Ayotzinapa that disappeared in 2014. Between 50 and 100 hooded demonstrators known as 'Bloque Negro' ('Black Bloc') vandalized stores and public transport premises along Reforma, painting facades and causing damages with sticks, mallets, and Molotov cocktails. Some of the stores were set on fire with gasoline. Rioters also threw Molotov cocktails at the National Palace. This event is part of a nationwide call in commemoration of the tenth anniversary of the disappearance of the students that includes demonstrations in other cities (coded separately).

assoc_actor_2: Government of Mexico (2018-); MC: Citizens' Movement; Students (Mexico)
source: 24 Horas (Mexico); Imagen del Golfo; Riodoce; Tabasco Hoy
notes: On 10 September 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, for the eighth consecutive day, hundreds of citizens, students, judges and employees of the Judiciary protested against the judicial reform. Protesters used tubes, fire-extinguishers and knives to force the doors of the Senate of the Republic and enter the building. Police officers used fire-extinguishing foam and water with soap to disperse the protesters. Inside, senators were holding a session on the reform, which was suspended and transferred to the Senate's alternative headquarters in Casona de Xicotencatl. Protesters headed to Casona, where a group of them assaulted a senator of the Citizens' Movement party by throwing gasoline into his eyes. Police officers intervened again, and suspectedly used tear gas and fire-extinguishing powder to disperse the protesters on Eje Central, Tacuba and 5 de Mayo streets. The Secretariat of Public Safety (SSC) later published a statement denying the use of tear gas. Also in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, students and members of the association 'Youth for Reform' protested in support of the judicial reform on Madrid street and Insurgentes avenue, a few meters from the demonstration against the reform, and around Casona de Xicotencatl on 5 de Mayo, Donceles, Tacuba and Republica de Cuba streets, where they blocked the access to senators. These protests are part of a national strike that includes protests in other cities (coded separately).

Some sources indicate that demonstrators intend to maintain the blockade until October, to prevent president-elect Claudia Sheinbaum from taking office. The demonstration was joined by people who marched in caravans from other states. Among the participants there were the president of the SCJN and the president of the PRI. On Madrid street, a group of people grabbed by the neck and beat at least three journalists, whom they blamed for blocking the access of senators from opposition parties. An alternative version indicates that, according to some demonstrators, infiltrated provocateurs might have promoted the clash.

Around 24 August 2024 (as reported), in Santiago de Queretaro, Queretaro, around 50 members and sympathetic to MORENA overstepped the state police perimeter and entered the Congress Centre in Teatro Metropolitano, where the recently elected Attorney General of Queretaro was assuming his duties, to denounce suspected irregularities in his election process. Once inside, the protesters engaged in shoving and shouting.

On 24 August 2024, in Heroica Matamoros, Tamaulipas, judges and employees of the Judiciary marched from Parque Olimpico to the General Consulate of the United States to protest against the reform promoted by the government to elect judges and the Supreme Court by popular vote and to support the statement made by the U.S. Ambassador to Mexico rejecting the reform. The protest is part of a national and indefinite strike that includes protests in other cities (coded separately).

Around 24 August 2024 (as reported), in Merida, Yucatan, over 600 hundred judges and employees of the Judiciary marched from 59, 60 and 47 streets to Francisco de Montejo plaza to protest against the reform promoted by the government to elect judges and the Supreme Court by popular vote. The protest is part of a national and indefinite strike that includes protests in other cities (coded separately).

Around 24 August 2024 (as reported), in Progreso, Yucatan, members of MORENA marched towards the Municipal Palace to reject the decision of the Regional Chamber of the Electoral Tribunal of the Federal Judiciary to overturn the annulment of the municipal elections, declaring the PAN and PRI candidate as the winner.

source: El Diario de Sonora; Entorno Informativo
notes: On 23 August 2024, in Hermosillo, Guanajuato, for the third consecutive day, over three hundred judges and employees of the Judiciary protested against the reform promoted by the government to elect judges and the Supreme Court by popular vote. The protest is part of a national and indefinite strike that includes protests in other cities (coded separately).

On 23 August 2024, in Monterrey, Nuevo Leon, employees of the Judiciary marched around Macroplaza and to Explanada de los Heroes in front of the State Palace to protest against the reform promoted by the government to elect judges and the Supreme Court by popular vote. The protest is part of a national and indefinite strike that includes protests in other cities (coded separately).

Around 23 August 2024 (as reported), in La Paz, Baja California Sur, employees of the XXVI Judicial Circuit, law firms and the Colleges of Doctors and Surgeons marched to protest against the reform promoted by the government to elect judges and the Supreme Court by popular vote.

assoc_actor_1: PAN: National Action Party; PRD: Party of the Democratic Revolution; PRI: Institutional Revolutionary Party; Strength and Heart for Mexico
notes: Around 23 August 2024 (as reported), in Ciudad de Mexico - Tlalpan, over 20 members of the so-called 'Marea Rosa' (including PAN, PRI and PRD parties, and the coalition Strength and Heart for Mexico ) protested in front of the Electoral National Institute against the electoral reforms proposed by President Manuel Lopez Obrador.

Around 23 August 2024 (as reported), in Hermosillo, Sonora, students of the Faculty of Psychology of the University of Sonora protested in front of the rector's office to demand security measures due to a student's violent behavior.

On 23 August 2024, in Pachuca de Soto, Hidalgo, around 50 art students of the Autonomous University of the State of Hidalgo blocked the access to the University Book Fair in the Poliforum to demand the university authorities to apologize for the violent clash between student and university employees during the demonstrations on 19 September 2023 (coded separately).

Around 23 August 2024 (as reported), in Pachuca de Soto, Hidalgo, normalista students of Escuela Normal Rural Luis Villarrea El Mexe school blocked Mexico-Pachuca federal road, close to the offices of the Secretary of Public Education of Hidalgo, to demand the reemployment of ten teachers, the dismissal of the teachers hired in their place, the construction of a dormitory for students from other municipalities and states, and the return of 72 hectares of land in the town of Tepatepec that the federal government assigned to El Mexe school in 1928.

On 23 August 2024, in Acapulco de Juarez, Guerrero, people affected by Hurricane Otis placed a chain in the access to Office 1 of the State Fiscal Administration, on Costera Miguel Aleman avenue in Fraccionamiento Costa Azul, to demand financial support to cope with the damages caused by the hurricane. The same group maintains a blockage of another office of the State Fiscal Administration in Colonia Centro since 12 August 2024 for the same reason (coded separately).

Around 23 August 2024 (as reported), in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, around 50 members of the Popular Congress of Ciudad de Mexico (CPCDMX) protested in front of the Hilton Hotel on Alemeda Central to reject the concessions of water wells granted by the federal government to large companies, including lodging service companies.

The municipal police intervened to reestablish traffic, which led to insults, pushing and hitting between the demonstrators and the officers. The demonstrators then marched towards the Municipal Palace and set fire to wires to use them to block the road leading to the palace.

notes: On 17 July 2024, near Tonanitla, Mexico, around 400 residents blocked at least five different points near the Felipe Angeles International Airport (AIFA), demanding the payment of owed resources after these were used to build the main access to the airport and respect for 850 hectares of their ejido that were being dispossessed by the municipality of Tecamac and for which they maintain a territorial boundary conflict. The rioters used burning tires, rocks, sticks, logs, tractors, machinery, and other vehicles to carry out the roadblocks. The roadblocks were in both directions of the Tonanitla-AIFA road, at the junctions with San Pedro and Las Valvulas and the intersection with the municipality of Tonanitla, at its main entrance, where about 70 people were blocking the access arch to the municipality.

notes: On 16 July 2024, in Ciudad de Mexico - Benito Juarez, residents of Santa Maria Coapan in Tehuacan protested at the offices of the Federal Attorney for Environmental Protection to demand the closure of the municipality's landfill. Amongst the protesters, there were representatives of the Zapatista Indigenous Agrarian Movement (MAIZ), Bienes de Pueblo de Santa Maria Coapan and the Union of Towns and Fractionations against the Garbage and in Defense of Water. They said that due to the contamination, several people have died from diseases and that there have been multiple violations of environmental regulations in the management of the landfill. The landfill was closed in 2022 but the demonstrators fear that the elected municipal president will enable it once again.
